column26:
I hope the "Code Academy Way" manifests into a type of communitas. A quick reference from wikipedia: "Communitas is an intense community spirit, the feeling of great social equality, solidarity, and togetherness. Communitas is characteristic of people experiencing liminality together. This term is used to distinguish the modality of social relationship from an area of common living."

Many people write about experiencing communitas in rites of passage situations, and I like to think the Code Academy experience is nothing short of that. We've made the choice to somewhat separate ourselves from our normal way of life for the next three months in order to pursue a common goal of becoming great developers. "This brings everyone onto an equal level: even if you are higher in position, you have been lower and you know what that is."

The mentorships, the openness and togetherness of co-working, social outings, and a shared work ethic all move towards this feeling of community.

column25: I signed for Code Academy to learn how to learn agile web development at a place that has a vibrant community, motivated classmates and experienced teachers.  Development in general, and web development specifically, is about problem solving.  While the developer must adapt to address a wide assortment of changing problems, going through a program like Code Academy will help one better navigate the ever changing tides and shoals of modern web development.  There is no better place to do this than Code Academy.
column26:
I would like to see Code Academy have a culture that promotes the pursuit of possibilities and engaging big important problems and not fall into the trap of developing a "me too" mindset.   In order to promote this, teachers and mentors should help every student form his or her individual learning map for the near, middle and long term.  Students should have some project on which to work, and mentors should guide the students to help learn how to make the projects a reality.   Good industry tools and practices are key, and rigor should be emphasized in both theoretical and practical terms.   

What I would *really* like to see is Code Academy venture into the less privileged areas of Chicago as a group or as students.  Programming is a powerful tool than can meaningfully work to improve communities.  There are a lot of socio-economic problems, and programmers can help leverage limited resources to help tackle challenges for social good.   This only works if there is engagement where engagement is needed most acutely.

column25:
• To learn to code
• To get involved in the Chicago tech and entrepreneurial community
• Mostly, I’m looking to be a part of something that matters. The foundations of how we approach business, how we communicate, connect and choose are changing. I think there is value in talking about what it means to be human in an increasingly digital world. And I think Chicago is an excellent place to be during all this change. I’m ready to be around people who are not only aware of the change but are actors in it. And I think Code Academy is that place.

column25:
I'm from a really, really small farm town. How I ended up lusting over technology instead of John Deere tractors is beyond me, so I definitely didn't fit in with the majority... at all. 

As just about every entrepreneur in the class knows, we don't fit in with most people... anywhere. We take big risks for bigger rewards and we're driven by something we usually can't put a finger on. 

Code Academy is a fantastic opportunity to add web development to my skill set and network with people just as passionate as I am. Signing up was a no-brainer.
column26:
I think one of the essential gears in the Code Academy clockwork is the same gear that keeps bars in business. The social aspect. Sure, you could have a beer at home, but we all know it's better in good company.

I could learn to code on my own, it'd difficult, but it could be done. What I couldn't do on my own is leverage the expansive circle of designers, developers and entrepreneurs that Code Academy has brought together.

To this end, I am a big proponent of social outings (whirleyball!), working in teams, meeting with mentors or anything that promotes relationship building.  I will be sure to take full advantage of ALL of these opportunities.  In the classroom, I hope everyone is focused at the task-at-hand and tries to get the most knowledge out of Codeacademy as possible.

column35: I learned how to work through the problems of teaching myself to program. In Shay's awesome course, I discovered how to supplement an online course with the resources to solve the problems that you come across as you build off of online coursework. I discovered how important semantics are as your projects become larger and how careful planning and hard work up front make your life much easier down the road. Carolyn opened my eyes to the world of "Don't Make Me Think" and I now cringe every time I experience a terrible user experience. I didn't fully realize how much I had learned until I worked with a team of developers and explained to them some of the concepts that I have been absorbing through the UX class.
